text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This IRM provides an overview of the Compliance Strategy Development Process
(1) Revised the hyperlink for Policy Statement 1-236 in IRM 4.70.5.1.5 to shift to the new IRM location.
This incorporates Interim Guidance Memo TE/GE-04-0819-0015, Consolidation of policy statements and delegation orders into two new IRM sections .
AUDIENCE
The primary users of this IRM are Tax Exempt & Government Entities (TE/GE) personnel and others by TE/GE’s shift toward issue-based identiﬁcation.
Table of Contents
Audience: The primary users of this IRM are TE/GE employees and others impacted by TE/GE’s shift toward issue-based identiﬁcation.
On May 1, 2017, TE/GE formed the CP&C office to streamline and consolidate processes that identify, research, select and monitor inventory using data

Authorizes the operation of the CSDP. Governs the identiﬁcation, selection, assignment, and allocation of resources for all compliance and enforcement activities for TE/GE taxpayers. Considers proposals from Issue Identiﬁcation and Research (IIR) Manager and Issue Development Specialists (IDSs), resulting from CSDP. Approves proposals for implementation or recommends other actions commensurate with compliance risk and resources.
TE/GE (
) The Board’s Chair is responsible for presiding over meetings and tive activities (for example, preparing agendas and meeting minutes). (

) CP&C’s responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following tasks: a. Aligns work with TE/GE’s strategic goals. b. Collaborates across the various areas of TE/GE to improve taxpayer compliance. c. Analyzes the submissions. d. Develops return selection ﬁlters. e. Prepares and reviews developed Compliance Strategies for to the Board. f. Manages data sources. g. Delivers work to the TE/GE functional offices. h. Maintains the Portal. (
) Classiﬁcation: The group within the Classiﬁcation & Case Assignment function in CP&C responsible for classifying cases. See IRM
for information on Classiﬁcation. (
) Classiﬁer: A person in the C&CA function who classiﬁes Compliance Strate- gies. (
) Compliance Governance Board (the “Board”): See IRM
, above. (
) Compliance Strategy: An issue developed through the CSDP and approved the Board. TE/GE uses them to identify, prioritize and allocate resources TE/GE taxpayers. (
) Exam Director: The Examination Director in EO or EP and the Director, ernment Entities. (
) Issue Development Specialist (IDS): The analysts in TE/GE Issue and Research group(s) (IIR group) review submissions, develop proposals make recommendations for compliance action(s) to the Board. (

) Issue Development Team (ID team): The team of experts brought together the IDS to participate in the CSDP. This may include employees from the functions and from the Knowledge Networks (K-Nets), Communications Liaison, Leadership Education and Delivery Services (LEADS) and/or ance unit(s) (i.e., EOCU, EPCU, or GECU). (
) Issue Identiﬁcation and Research and Special Review (II&SR): A function within CP&C that is responsible for issue identiﬁcation, research and review. (
) Issue Identiﬁcation and Research Manager (IIR manager): The frontline manager of an IIR group. (

) Research: This team is part of Issue Identiﬁcation and Research (IIR) and staffed with analysts, economists, and statisticians who continually provide analytical support to Issue ID throughout the development process and respond to ad hoc data requests.
The Board’s Chair is responsible for presiding over meetings and administra- tive activities (for example, preparing agendas and meeting minutes).
CP&C’s responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following tasks:

) The IRS has some main objectives surrounding workload selection: • Selecting cases or compliance strategies that will have the positive impact on voluntary compliance and tax administration • Selecting work in an unbiased manner without retaliating against, harassing, a taxpayer (see IRM

) CP&C was created to address concerns regarding the separation of tion, workload selection and examination activities. (
) Program Reports: Within CP&C, electronic systems are used to house documents related to CSDP. Access to the system is restricted. (

) TE/GE ensures that adequate and effective controls are in place during development, approval and execution of Compliance Strategies. offices within TE/GE will provide resources to assist in the development take appropriate actions as submissions move through the CSDP. (

) Program Effectiveness: a. The Board: • Analyzes and reviews program goals • Considers information, including related metrics in the reports • Determines whether the approved Compliance Strategy should continue, be modiﬁed or be discontinued b. Documentation submitted to the Board for review includes: • Summary reports from P&M • Feedback from the IDS • Periodic feedback c. CP&C:

• Selecting cases or compliance strategies that will have the highest positive impact on voluntary compliance and tax administration • Selecting work in an unbiased manner without retaliating against, or harassing, a taxpayer (see IRM
and Section

Program Reports: Within CP&C, electronic systems are used to documents related to CSDP. Access to the system is restricted.

TE/GE ensures that adequate and effective controls are in place during the development, approval and execution of Compliance Strategies. Functional offices within TE/GE will provide resources to assist in the development and take appropriate actions as submissions move through the CSDP.
(06-02-2021) Compliance Strategy Development Process (CSDP)
a. Use internal and external data sources to their fullest potential. b. Encourage collaboration and effective use of the K
Nets and other subject matter experts. c. Select compliance treatments that will effectively and efficiently impact non
compliance. d. Identify key measures for monitoring success. e. Reﬂect on the results of each compliance treatment and re
evaluate compliance treatments, when needed.
The IIR Group(s) includes IDSs with various technical backgrounds from the TE/GE functional offices (EP and EO/GE) and also includes Research.

(4) Section A of the template contains sub-sections for the K-Net and IDS (5) The chart below describes each section of the template: Phase Action Section Purpose Proposal Submis- A – Issue Sub- Identiﬁes an issue where sion mission the submitter has seen non-compliance or the potential for non- compliance. Prelimi- B – Issue Identi- Documents issue charac- nary ﬁcation teristics, evaluates Review compliance history and documents initial decision whether to proceed with issue development. C – Issue De- Documents ID Team velopment Team members. (ID Team) D – Issue De- Documents the develop- velopment Plan ment of ID Team’s preliminary plan to identify and address the potential non-compliance. Also, documents brieﬁng on pre- liminary issue development plan with the appropriate Exam Director. Issue De- E – Case Identi- Documents the sources velopment ﬁcation and techniques used to Methodology identify non-compliant returns/taxpayers. Phase Action Section Purpose H – Tools and Documents instructions to Training Recom- Classiﬁcation, training mendations needs, compliance tools required and outreach needs for implementing a proposal. Compli- Approval I – Board Documents the Board’s ance Outcome/ comments and decision. Strategy ApprovedStrategy Work J – Issue After the Board approves Plan Treatment Plan proposal and it is ready to be incorporated into the work plan, documents actual Compliance Strate- gies approved for work plan and proper inventory tracking codes used to monitor progress of approved workstreams. Follow-up K – Evaluation Documents results, based Process on P&M reports for approved Compliance Strategies.
CSDP’s main goal is to identify areas of potential non
compliance as soon possible. All employees are encouraged to make submissions when non
compliance may be present in a broader population. Non
compliance may be identiﬁed by: a. Employees in TE/GE ﬁeld groups or compliance units. b. Employees working within Voluntary Compliance programs (VC). c. K

Net members. d. Other TE/GE employees. A submission to the Portal should only include ONE issue. The Portal is NOT for examination tips, asking questions or requesting form changes. The submitter must: a. Describe the issue. b. Include the section of the IRC related to the issue. c. Include the tax form related to the issue. d. Explain how the issue was identiﬁed. e. Identify additional ways to identify the issue, if known.
Include the section of the IRC related to the issue. Include the tax form related to the issue. Explain how the issue was identiﬁed. Identify additional ways to identify the issue, if
The submitter may include attachments to the submission but Personally Iden- tiﬁable Information (PII) or Sensitive but Unclassiﬁed (SBU) is NOT allowed.
After the submitter receives the initial e-mail, typically, no further feedback will be provided to protect work selection processes and procedures.
An e-mail notiﬁcation is sent to the IDS, when the ID Manager assigns the submission. New submissions are evaluated monthly for assignment
Opens the submission. Reviews the submission and if needed, contacts the submitter for addi

tional information. Reviews the IRC section in the submission for accuracy, and if corrects Section A of the template. Conducts a preliminary review of the submission. Decides whether to proceed with preliminary development, combine it with another related submission or reject the submission. Records his/her ﬁndings in Section B of the template.
Based upon the Exam Director’s concurrence with the proposal, the IDS will continue to develop the issue for presentation to the Board.

Internal sources include information from ﬁled tax and information returns, as well as prior compliance activity results. External sources may include publicly available information including data from other federal, state and local governments provided to the IRS.
Some internal IRS information is not readily available because it is not tran- scribed and/or is not a searchable ﬁeld in system databases.

) The proposal becomes a Compliance Strategy only when the Board it. (
) The Board notiﬁes the function’s designated person within ﬁve regarding approved Compliance Strategies. (

) Once a proposal has Board approval, the IDS updates the template to the Board’s approval. The IDS begins to execute the treatment
(06-02-2021) Board Approval of the Proposal
IIR Manager posts proposal documents and ﬁnal PowerPoint slide deck for presentation, to the Board’s SharePoint site (restricted access).
Once a proposal has Board approval, the IDS updates the template to the Board’s approval. The IDS begins to execute the treatment plan(s).
TE/GE (

) The ID Team: a. Determines how to execute the treatment plan, based on the Plan workstreams. b. Develops any relevant tools, documents, and other information c. Periodically reports out progress made on the Compliance Strategy Board. (
) If an approved Compliance Strategy needs to be modiﬁed, the IDS should consult the IIR Manager to determine whether the recommended changes need to be presented to the Board for approval. (
) IDS requests project and/or tracking codes from P&M. Once received, the will document the assigned codes in the template. (
) The ID Team prepares any needed instructions for Classiﬁcation. (

) The ID Team prepares a cover sheet, describing the issue and any audit to be taken in determining whether the issue exists. If applicable, the cover sheet prepared by the ID Team mentions by name the training and K-net resources speciﬁcally identiﬁed for the Compliance Strategy. This will be uploaded into the RCCMS ﬁle. (
) The IDS forwards the cover sheet, the instructions for the Classiﬁer and identiﬁed cases, in the form of a list or query, to P&M for consideration in planning work. (
) CP&C provides post-strategy monitoring and periodic updates to the (
) The Board considers the progress of all implemented Compliance Process (
) P&M gives the IDS and the Board feedback and metrics to help them determine whether a Compliance Strategy should be continued, modiﬁed terminated. (

) Research supports the IDS with CSDP and develops, maintains and data-driven compliance efforts for: • Case Selection Models • Hospital Report • Customer Satisfaction Survey • Other TE/GE Executive ad hoc requests (
) The IIR manager coordinates with RAAS when either the CSDP or the IDS needs additional support and expertise that is not available in the group. (
) The Case Selection Models are a collection of queries that Research uses evaluate the audit potential of information and other returns under TE/GE Models diction. (
) Case selection models are a technique that Research uses to: a. Score certain TE/GE returns as to audit potential. Selection Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
R
The Case Selection Models are a collection of queries that Research uses to evaluate the audit potential of information and other returns under TE/GE juris-
Case selection models are a technique that Research uses to:
Score certain TE/GE returns as to audit potential.
Note: Weights are added together to obtain a composite score for each return.
Note: Weights are added together to obtain a composite score for each return. (

) Research: a. Uses this composite score to systematically rank the returns in sequence (highest to lowest). Generally, the higher the score, the the probability of an issue warranting audit. b. Provides the scored returns to Classiﬁcation twice a year to ﬁll return orders. (
) Return scoring is for Official Use Only (OUO) and should not be disclosed discussed with unauthorized personnel. (

) Research: a. Works with IIR to develop new issue-speciﬁc queries for models. b. Develops models for TE/GE returns - Developing models for case selection is a continuous process. Research may develop other based on forms under TE/GE jurisdiction as the need arises. c. Submits the models to the Board for approval. d. Maintains the master list of queries in the model. (
) The Board reviews and approves substantial changes to existing models any new models before each update cycle. (
) The Affordable Care Act (ACA) §
) requires reporting to the annually. The annual report includes speciﬁc information on private, tax- exempt, taxable, and government-owned hospitals. (

) Research assists TE/GE Headquarters (HQ) by providing summary and trends for the annual report, using data from the Centers for Medicare Medicaid Services (CMS), reporting hospital cost report data for each cost report year, and Form
Schedule H data ﬁles provided by Statistics of Income. (
) The Customer Satisfaction Survey is conducted as part of the IRS wide initiative (RRA
and Executive Order

) to monitor and taxpayer satisfaction with the service provided. The objectives of this to: a. Track customer satisfaction over time. b. Identify areas where improvements will have the greatest impact on customer satisfaction. c. Encompass TE/GE customers from every function and include both examinations and determinations programs. (
) Research is responsible for: • Coordinating with the survey contractor and the print contractor to sure the program runs smoothly • Data analysis • Report writing Internal Revenue Manual
